title: 105_hr3143
content:
The Act titled "Comprehensive Holocaust Accountability in Insurance Measure" prohibits certain foreign insurance companies. The Act titled "Comprehensive Holocaust Accountability in Insurance Measure" prohibits specific foreign insurance companies from conducting business in the United States unless they disclose financial dealings with individuals on Holocaust survivor lists. The Act requires foreign insurance companies to disclose financial dealings with Holocaust survivors, with designated disclosures made to the Attorney General's office for public availability. TITLE II--PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO UNITED STATES BANKING INSTITUTIONS

SEC. 201. LIMITATION ON INSURED DEPOSITORY INSTITUTIONS. Section 18 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act is amended to prohibit insured depository institutions from engaging in financial transactions with certain foreign insurance companies or their affiliates for a specified period after the enactment of the Comprehensive Holocaust Accountability in Insurance Measure. The Comprehensive Holocaust Accountability in Insurance Measure prohibits insured depository institutions from engaging in financial transactions with certain foreign insurance companies or their affiliates. There is a limited exception for affiliates allowing payment of dividends and investment in the institution. The payment or investment described in the Comprehensive Holocaust Accountability in Insurance Measure must comply with regulations set by the Attorney General or the appropriate Federal banking agency. LIMITATION ON UNINSURED BRANCHES, AGENCIES, AND COMMERCIAL LENDING COMPANY AFFILIATES OF FOREIGN BANKS. The International Banking Act of 1978 is amended to prohibit certain transactions with foreign insurance companies or their affiliates. This includes restrictions on accepting deposits, providing payment services, participating in payment systems, extending credit, or engaging in financial activities with listed foreign insurance companies or their affiliates. The International Banking Act of 1978 is amended to restrict transactions with foreign insurance companies or their affiliates, including limitations on dividends, stock investments, and capital injections by foreign insurance companies or their affiliates in branches, agencies, or commercial lending companies controlled by foreign banks. The International Banking Act of 1978 is amended to restrict transactions with foreign insurance companies or their affiliates, including limitations on dividends, stock investments, and capital injections. Payments or investments must comply with regulations set by the Attorney General, the Board, the Comptroller of the Currency, or the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
